Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Medium: Understanding and designing for online disclosure and its effects on well-being

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
From mundane details of daily life to tragic warnings of planned suicide, people exchange a massive amount of personal information in social media that defies traditional models of self-disclosure. This project will advance understanding of personal information disclosure in social media contexts and will use this information to develop well-being interventions designed to enhance self-reflection and capacity to productively seek and offer support. Such interventions benefit individuals and society overall by helping people know how and from where to seek support in informal and formal social networks. Knowledge about key drivers of self-disclosure will also be useful in improving the design of other systems that use personal data and will inform public discussions about the use and risks of personal information online. The PIs will work to raise awareness of disclosure benefits and risks through users' participation in experiments, use of systems, and publicizing research results beyond the research community, e.g., by working to move research results into practical applications through the Bronfenbrenner Center for Translational Research at Cornell.

More specifically, this research will yield a multi-theoretical and multi-level model of how individual attributes such as personality and mental health status, technological affordances such as reviewability and audience visibility, and social network properties such as size, density, diversity, and tie strength, individually and in combination, shape anticipated rewards and risks of disclosure and disclosure strategies. These models will incorporate responses by network members into the production cycle of disclosure, and examine how these combined characteristics determine both anticipated and actual outcomes. The researchers will collect examples of actual disclosure behaviors in both text and photos, annotated with information about people's disclosure goals and perceptions, individual characteristics, and social networks, and will use these to validate predictive models of the presence of and responses to disclosure in social media data. These models will help identify when people create meaningful content, which in turn can be used in systems and interventions that support the well-being of social media users, both in the general population and those at risk. These systems and interventions will operate by using disclosed information to facilitate reflection, enrich existing positive psychology interventions, and promote awareness of and effective responses to disclosure and mental health needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in new knowledge in the areas of self-disclosure and privacy in social media; well-being, mental health; bystander interventions and cyberbullying; social norms and behavioral contagion; sensitive and stigmatized disclosures; relational dynamics over mobile and social media; multi-media and multi-platform communication; and social robots and conversational agents. Over the life of the award, we have produced 30 publications in journals and conference proceedings, presented our work at various conferences, developed novel socio-technical interventions, organized a methodological workshop, and formed interdisciplinary collaborations and partnerships with external organizations, such as Common Sense and New York State 4-H Programs. This project has resulted in training opportunities for 2 post-doctorate associates, 10 graduate students, and over 40 undergraduate students who participated in research and outreach activities, including training in cutting-edge research methods, such as ecological momentary assessments, naturalistic social media experiments, longitudinal log data collection and analyses, and designing social media and VR interventions.

Additionally, this project resulted in a novel platform Truman for social media experimentation. This platform mimics a social media site by using pre-programmed bots that produce social media content and behave as real participants on the site. As such, this platform allows to recreate a realistic social media experience while giving researchers full control over a technical and social infrastructure of the site. To date, we have conducted five studies with this platform, three of which are already published, and have conducted a workshop to disseminate this tool to a broader scientific community.

Another significant outcome is Social Media TestDrive, a realistic social media simulation platform that teaches young people digital citizenship skills through participation in experiential learning. The platform features 12 modules, each centered on key digital citizenship concepts (e.g., stopping cyberbullying, information literacy, awareness of digital footprints, ups and downs of social media). These learning modules provide interactive counterparts to Digital Citizenship lessons from Common Sense Education linked with the corresponding lessons on the Common Sense site. It is widely disseminated at a national scale through our partnership with Common Sense and Wide Open School, and locally in New York State through our collaboration with New York State 4-H Educators.
